IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: Black Men Teach (BMT) recruits, prepares, places, and retains Black male teachers in elementary schools by building a robust pathway to the teaching profession, beginning in high school and continuing to support men through college and into their teaching career. BMT began in 2018 based on research that told us that a diverse teacher corps improves student outcomes for all children, especially children of color. Black students in elementary school who have at least one Black male teacher are 29% less likely to drop out of school. Those who have two Black male teachers are 32% more likely to enroll in post-secondary education. Since its start in 2018, BMT has gone from a start-up, to serving 12 Black men in 2020, 42 in 2021 and 63 in 2022. To support our rapid ramp up in programming, our staffing and budgeted spend are ramping up. We are developing a coalition of schools, school districts, teacher training and scholarship programs, and community organizations to achieve this objective.
IRS990.MissionDesc: Black Men Teach (BMT) recruits, prepares, places, and retains Black male teachers in elementary schools by building a robust pathway to the teaching profession, beginning in high school and continuing to support men through college and into their teaching career. BMT began in 2018 based on research that told us that a diverse teacher corps improves student outcomes for all children, especially children of color. Black students in elementary school who have at least one Black male teacher are 29% less likely to drop out of school. Those who have two Black male teachers are 32% more likely to enroll in post-secondary education. Since its start in 2018, BMT has gone from a start-up, to serving 12 Black men in 2020, to 75 in fiscal 2023. To support our rapid ramp up in programming, our staffing and budgeted spend are ramping up. We are developing a coalition of schools, school districts, teacher training and scholarship programs, and community organizations to achieve this objective.
IRS990.Desc: Student Loan Repayment Program (SLRP). Most teachers graduate school with student loan debt, and Black men have significantly more debt than their white counterparts. This burden often leads men to leave the profession. SLRP pays off the principal amount of student debt held by practicing teachers over a five-year period. For fiscal 2023 fifteen men were directly supported by this program and approximately 390 elementary school students benefited from them remaining in the classroom.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: Student Teaching Stipend - Student teaching, required to earn a degree and become a licensed teacher, is a significant financial burden for students. Because this activity is full time, for a period of 12 to 16 weeks, it precludes the student from earning outside income from a full or part time job. Therefore, many students leave the teaching track at this late stage because of this burden. BMT assists its teaching candidates by providing a stipend during this part of their education. In fiscal 2023, five student teachers benefited from this program as did approximately 100 elementary school students who were exposed to a Black male teacher.

ProgSrvcAccomActy3Grp.Desc: Scholarships-In an effort to offset the financial burden their education, Black Men Teach offers up to $20,000 scholarships to its participants. These scholarships are provided to men who are active participants in our program and are paid at an accelerated rate over four years. The scholarships are $2,000 during the freshman year, $4,000 during the sophomore year, $6,000 during the junior year and $8,000 during the senior year. To qualify, students provide BMT with transcripts, confirming their class status, current course schedules, academic credits and fee statements. BMT offers these as "last dollar" scholarships. In the fiscal 2023, fifteen received scholarships.

ProgSrvcAccomActyOtherGrp.Desc: This being the third full year of Black Men Teach with an executive director and paid staff, much of our program expense was focused on staff time acquiring partnerships with elementary schools, scholarship programs and teacher training programs, as well as on-campus meetings with potential teacher candidates, teaching high school classes introducing seniors to teaching as a career, and much more. In addition to grants in the three primary service areas, other grants included for men obtaining their teacher license through an alternative certification program and to leadership/instructional coaches.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: BMT requested funding from the state of Minnesota. Our executive director spoke to several legislators about the request and encouraged them to vote in favor of the funding. He also testified before two legislative committees. His total hours were five which equals approximately $500 of expense.

Black Men Teach is organized as a Minnesota nonprofit corporation and has been recognized by the IRS as exempt from federal income taxes under IRS Section 501(c). The Organization is annually required to file a Return of Organization Exempt from Income Tax (Form 990) with the IRS. In addition, the Organization is subject to income taxes on net income that is derived from business activities that are unrelated to its exempt purpose. The Organization believes it is not subject to unrelated business income tax and has not filed an Exempt Organization Income Tax Return (Form 990-T) with the IRS.

FundraiserActivityInfoGrp.ActivityTxt: General fund raising, focusing on grants from corporations and foundations
General fundraising, focus on individual gifts

GrantsOtherAsstToIndivInUSGrp.GrantTypeTxt: Student loan repayments These grants were provided to current educators to assist them in paying their student loan debt over 5 years. These teachers were selected in one of two ways. An initial group, in which all Black male educators across the Twin Cities area qualified, was selected in 2021 via and objective and competitive process using non-affiliated community members to assist in the assessment process. Additionally, all Black male teachers which BMT places in our partner schools qualify. Payments are made directly to the loan servicer of each teacher to ensure proper use of grant funds. Additionally, these men have their employment status as teachers validated each year by staff to ensure they continue to qualify for the five-year repayment program.

Stipends for student teachers As part of their education and to earn degree and teaching license in Minnesota, Elementary Education students are required to do a student teaching practicum of between 12 and 16 weeks. Due to the intensity of the experience, student teaching generally precludes outside employment and the opportunity to earn an income. To reduce the financial burden, Black Men Teach provides stipends to college students performing their student teaching. BMT makes this stipend available to teachers who have been active participants in its programs, and confirms student participation with both the students' college or university and the school in which they do their practicum.

Scholarships In an effort to offset the financial burden of their education, Black Men Teach offers $20,000 scholarships to its participants. These scholarships are provided men who are active participants in our program and are paid an an increasing rate over four years. The scholarships are normally $2,000 during the freshman year, $4,000 during the sophomore year, $6,000 during the junior year, and $8,000 during the senior year. To qualify, students provide BMT with transcripts confirming their class status, current course schedules, academic credits and fee statements. BMT offers these as "last dollar" scholarships, meaning we cover only that portion of student's tuition, up to the amounts noted above, that are not covered by other scholarships or financial support offered by their school.
Other Includes grants for men obtaining teaching license through alternative certification programs, grants to leadership/instructional coaches, and other program related grants.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The use of grant funds is monitored as follows: student loan repayments are made directly to the teacher's loan servicer after verifying the teacher is still eligible for the program; student teaching stipends are paid after verifying with both the university and the elementary school that student is eligible and is student teaching; scholarships are paid directly to the college after verifying the student is eligible.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, Line 1a
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: BMT has an Executive Committee which consists of the Board Chair, and the Chairs of the standing committees. Unless otherwise provided by the Board of Directors, during intervals between meetings of the Board of Directors the Executive Committee has the power to take action that may be taken by the Board of Directors, other than power to: remove or appoint directors, committee members or officers; amend or repeal the bylaws; amend or repeal any vote or action taken by the Board of Directors; or exercise any other power that the directors are prohibited by law from delegating. Any action take by the Executive Commitee is reported to the Board of Directors at the next board meeting.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 11b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The 990 draft was reviewed by our auditors, CLA, reviewed by our Finance Committee and a draft was provided to our board members and discussed at a board meeting prior to filing.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Annually, the conflict of interest policy is provided to directors and employees, and there is a process to ensure that each director and employee returns a signed copy. The process is monitored by the chair of the Governance Committee. Any potential conflicts of interest identified are brought to the full board for discussion and resolution.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: BMT's Board of Directors uses salary and compensation data provided by the Minnesota Council of NonProfits, which is updated annually, as a reference in determining the Executive Director's compensation package. For other positions, and as per board policy, the Executive Director provides the Executive Committee with position descriptions and salary recommendations. The salary recommendations also use the MN Council of NP as a reference. The Executive Commitee approves the salaries.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, Line 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: These documents are made available by request.
